awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Development of a Novel Surgical Navigation System for Total Knee Replacement
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer Program (STTR) Phase I project is the significant improvement in orthopedic care associated with (1) the broad expansion of patient access to improved procedures through significant cost reduction; and (2) better outcomes through patient-specific surgical interventions. Existing advanced technology for surgical navigation has failed to address the clinical needs and financial realities for healthcare providers, resulting in a low adoption rate, despite demand from orthopedic surgeons, hospitals, and patients for advanced technology solutions. Less than 15% of joint replacement surgeries performed in the United States today utilize advanced technology, despite superior clinical outcomes, presenting a significant commercial opportunity to address an unmet market need that will reach $5 billion globally by 2026. The proposed technology radically reduces the cost of an advanced surgical navigation system and improves outcomes.  

This Small Business Technology Transfer Program (STTR) Phase I project focuses on developing leading-edge, low-cost surgical navigation to help orthopedic surgeons achieve precise, personalized implant fit and placement for all joint replacement patients. Existing navigation and robotic systems for joint replacement have high upfront and recurring costs. They add time and complexity to the surgical procedure and require additional and larger incisions to accommodate invasive pins used to affix trackers to the patient's bones. The proposed system utilizes advanced 3D scanning to map patient anatomy and proprietary radar tracking technology to help surgeons fit and place implants ideally for each patient. This phase I project aims to achieve the following technical objectives: (1) validation of high resolution radar tracking accuracy, (2) implementation of 3D scanning to register patient imaging data to their anatomy, and (3) validation of a surgical planning system to personalize the procedure to each patient using an anatomic computational model of the joint and relevant soft tissues.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
This project seeks to meet a broad societal need for solutions to address accelerating demand for joint replacement surgery. In 2017, there were 1.2 million joint replacement procedures in the US comprising approximately 58.5% of worldwide procedure volume. By 2026, procedure volume is projected to increase 44% to 2.6 million procedures annually. In a value-based care environment, where surgeons and hospitals are required to do more with less, Caira Surgical is developing novel new technologies to decrease cost and modernize and improve the standard of care in joint replacement surgery. 

The technology developed in this Phase I project seeks to expand patient and provider access to advanced surgical technology through enabling a new generation of surgical navigation and robotics that improve surgical accuracy and repeatability, simplify the procedure and decrease surgical and long term costs through improving outcomes. The first application for this technology will be for Total Knee Replacement (TKR). Caira plans to expand applications to partial knee replacement, hip and shoulder replacement and spinal procedures. 

The goal of the Phase 1 project was to advance the development of a novel surgical navigation system employing advanced 3D scanning technologies and radar-based motion tracking in a low-cost computer-assisted surgical (CAS) system. Despite advances in computer assisted surgical systems for total joint replacement, there remain a variety of issues with contemporary systems. High upfront and recurring costs have limited computer assisted surgical systems to high volume providers, while several technical and user experience pain points still exist in current systems (slow registration, optical tracking line of sight, etc.). The CAIRA System is designed to mitigate each of these issues to provide a CAS solution for TKR that provides state-of-the-art guidance to cost conscious healthcare providers.

Technical hurdles that were addressed through this Phase I research include: performing proof of concept validation for the preoperative planning software and ligament force model, demonstrating accurate registration of 3D scanning of the tibia and femur and assessment of a Caira autoregistration tool, and demonstrating millimeter range accuracy tracking using radar. Each of these objectives were completed successfully. The computational model outputs (strain energy) were within 10% of the measured values for 5 knees. Displacement measurements used to calculate the strain energy were obtained at sub-millimeter accuracy. RMS error was less than 1mm for the 3D scanned surface of the femur and tibia of 5/6 cadaveric knees. Radar position measurements via signal processing techniques were less than 2mm.


 

 


Last Modified: 05/06/2022
Modified by: Jonathan Greenwald
